contentrichtext.text: {{about|the river in Tasmania|the river in England|River Tamar}} {{Geobox | River <!-- *** Name section *** --> | name = Tamar River | native_name = | other_name = | other_name1 = <!-- *** Image *** ---> | image = Tamar river.JPG | image_size = | image_caption = <!-- *** Country etc. *** --> | country = Australia | region = Tasmania | region1 = | city = Launceston, Tasmania | city1 = <!-- *** Geography *** --> | length = 70 | watershed = | discharge_location = | discharge_average = | discharge_max = | discharge_min = | discharge1_location = | discharge1_average = <!-- *** Source *** --> | source_name = | source_location = [[North Esk River]] and [[South Esk River]] | source_district = | source_region = | source_state = | source_country = | source_lat_d = | source_lat_m = | source_lat_s = | source_lat_NS = | source_long_d = | source_long_m = | source_long_s = | source_long_EW = | source_elevation = | source_length = <!-- *** Mouth *** --> | mouth_name = [[Low Head, Tasmania|Low Head]] | mouth_location = | mouth_district = | mouth_region = Bass Strait | mouth_state = | mouth_country = | mouth_lat_d = | mouth_lat_m = | mouth_lat_s = | mouth_lat_NS = | mouth_long_d = | mouth_long_m = | mouth_long_s = | mouth_long_EW = E | mouth_elevation = <!-- *** Tributaries *** --> | tributary_left = | tributary_left1 = | tributary_right = | tributary_right1 = <!-- *** Free fields *** --> | free_name = | free_value = <!-- *** Map section *** --> | map = | map_size = | map_caption = }} The '''Tamar River''' is a 70 kilometre [[Estuary|estuarine]] in northern [[Tasmania]] formed by the merging of the [[North Esk River]] and [[South Esk River]]s at [[Launceston, Tasmania|Launceston]] (the largest settlement) to its mouth at [[Low Head, Tasmania|Low Head]], north of the second largest settlement [[George Town, Tasmania|George Town]]<ref>http://www.georgetown.tas.gov.au</ref> and into the [[Bass Strait]]. [[Low Head Lighthouse]] is located at the tip of a peninsula, on the east side of the mouth of the Tamar River. The Tamar River was named for the [[River Tamar]] in [[South West England]] by Colonel [[William Paterson (governor)|William Paterson]] in December 1804.<ref>{{Citation | editor=Bladen, F. M. (Frank Murcott) | title=Historical records of New South Wales, Volume 5—King, 1803-1805 | page=497 | publication-date=1897 | publisher=Charles Potter, Government Printer | location = Sydney | url=http://publications.nsw.gov.au/1117-historical-records-of-nsw-vol-5---king-1803-1804- }}</ref> Despite its name it is not actually a river as it is [[Saline water|saline]] and [[Tide|tidal]] over its entire length. The only full crossing of the Tamar is the [[Batman Bridge]] in the relatively remote area of [[Sidmouth, Tasmania|Sidmouth]], around halfway up the river. Although the Port of Launceston is now used very little in comparison to the past<ref>[http://www.launcestonhistory.org.au/2006/shipping1.htm The Development of the Port of Launceston, Launceston Historical Society]</ref> and the [[SeaCat Tasmania]] ferry no longer docks at George Town,<ref>http://users.nex.net.au/~reidgck/bass-s.htm</ref> the Tamar still is used for [[shipping]], with light and heavy industries at Georgetown (including aluminimum smelters) as well as commercial boat cruises.<ref>http://www.tamarrivercruises.com.au/</ref> ==See also== *[[Tamar Wetlands Important Bird Area]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Tamar River}} * [http://www.parks.tas.gov.au/reserves/tamar/history.pdf History of the Tamar River Conservation Area] {{coord|41|04|S|146|47|E|display=title|region:AU_type:river_source:GNS-enwiki}} [[Category:Tamar River|*]] [[Category:Rivers of Tasmania]] {{Tasmania-geo-stub}}
